title: Does a failed accusation invalidate the term of office, allowing for re-election?
subtitle: On the other hand, if the president is isolated (but not convicted), does he prevent this person from running for a second term?
author: Dan Evon
vclaim: The Constitution of the United States provides that if a president is removed by the House of Representatives but not convicted by the Senate, the first term of office of that person shall be abolished and be eligible for two more nominations.
